awd_titl_txt: CMU REU Site in Software Engineering (REUSE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Software engineering (SE) is a rich field focused on improving the effectiveness of software development through a variety of tools and techniques. Research in software engineering brings core aspects of computer science, such as
programming languages and machine learning, to bear on emerging software concerns such as privacy, security, mobility, and adaptability.  This project supports an ongoing Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Carnegie-Mellon University that provides students with training in interdisciplinary software engineering research,
including understanding the research literature, formulating and refining research questions, developing novel solutions to software engineering problems, and applying scientific evaluation methods. The project will support the
training of 30 undergraduate students over 3 years with research experiences in interdisciplinary software engineering at Carnegie Mellon University. These students will be recruited primarily from undergraduate-only institutions where students have limited research opportunities, with a special emphasis on providing opportunities to members of underrepresented groups in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) and first- and second-year students. Participants will perform research with faculty mentors, participate in community activities, and communicate their work both through traditional publication channels and student research competitions and
via department-wide presentations at the end of the summer.  A primary goal for the program is to improve the pipeline from college to graduate school and from graduate school into faculty positions; simultaneously, the site actively trains graduate students to act as effective mentors of research assistants, a critical skill for future faculty members.

While built on computer science fundamentals (like algorithms, programming languages, compilers, and machine learning), software engineering is simultaneously an engineering discipline.  That is, both the practice of SE and SE research problems revolve around technical solutions that successfully resolve conflicting constraints. As such, trade-offs between costs and benefits are an integral part of evaluating the effectiveness of methods and tools.  This REU site takes this further, by tackling research problems that are at the intersection of software engineering and another field, including privacy, security, mobility, and human psychology and other sciences.  A subset of these problems includes, among others:
* Sustainable maintenance of critical open source infrastructure;
* Development of novel programming languages that can (A) support and enforce
critical security properties or (B) support visualization of mathematical
diagrams and notation; 
* Encoding and analysis of privacy requirements across distributed,
service-oriented systems; and
* Automatic identification and repair of defects in complex, modern software
systems.
The project will build on the experience of many of the faculty mentors who have
worked with undergraduate students in their individual research.  This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of our REU site project was to increase undergraduate student interest and involvement in high-quality interdisciplinary software engineering research, and to enable more students to pursue scientific research careers.  This project specifically aimed to increase the involvement of students attending undergraduate-focused institutions (who often lack access to research opportunities at those institutions) as well as members of groups that are underrepresented in computer science, including women and other underserved minority groups. Our long-term goal has been to increase the number and diversity of students who pursue research careers by exposing a diverse set of students to research early, stimulating their interest in pursuing research long-term, and enabling them to do so, such as by successfully applying to graduate school programs.  


Over the course of this project, our summer research program received more than 1000 applicants over several summers. We were able to accept 101 summer scholars total, a subset of whom were directly supported by this project. The Broader Impacts of our work lie in how we broadened the pipeline of talented and energetic undergraduates pursuing a scientific research career.  More than half of our 101 students over three summers identified as women, and approximately a quarter as members of other underserved demographic groups in computing.  We also trained students from every type of undergraduate institution and at all undergraduate levels. We empowered our admissions committee to identify exceptional candidates from non-traditional backgrounds or lower-opportunity environments, so these easy-to-measure statistics reflect only a part of the diversity of our students.  The majority of the graduated students funded by this project ultimately applied to and enrolled at PhD programs, continuing their research careers.  


The students accomplished these outcomes by contributing to high-quality and novel research in interdisciplinary software engineering.  Because the students were mentored by different professors with varying expertise, the projects were themselves diverse and contributed a wide array of intellectual outcomes.  These projects included but were not limited to studies of how open source communities and development are changing and evolving over time, and how to keep open source development sustainable; new and evidence-based ways that websites should best present cookie consent interfaces to users; new ways to design effective programming languages in user-centric ways; novel techniques for automatically converting programs to use different libraries; and more.  Over the course of their time working with us, our students contributed to a large number of peer-reviewed publications, at a diversity of top conferences across the research area our Site represents. Our students also won a number of student research competitions and awards with their work, including sweeping the ACM student research competition held at the ACM SIGPLAN conference on Systems, Programming, Languages, and Applications: Software for Humanity in 2020.
